Title: A Game of Thrones (A Song of Ice and Fire, #1)
Author: George R.R. Martin

Title: A Clash of Kings  (A Song of Ice and Fire, #2)
Author: George R.R. Martin

Title: A Storm of Swords (A Song of Ice and Fire, #3)
Author: George R.R. Martin

Title: A Feast for Crows (A Song of Ice and Fire, #4)
Author: George R.R. Martin

Title: A Dance with Dragons (A Song of Ice and Fire, #5)
Author: George R.R. Martin

Title: The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review:
The book was nice at first, but as it progressed, it became more and more incoherent. Such is to be expected from a book which deals little with this reality and much with the parallel, darker kind of worlds. Although, the finishing was quite adeptly laid out, and the way everything came to an end and the explanations which are given is not unsatisfying, that is for sure.
The scenarios are vivid, and the feelings the writer wanted to express came to life with a certain grace, so I'd give him that, but as the only book I read of Murakami was Norwegian Woods, I wasn't certainly expecting something like this.
4 out of 5 stars seems fair to me.

Title: Murder on the Orient Express (Hercule Poirot, #10)
Author: Agatha Christie

Title: The Mysterious Affair at Styles (Hercule Poirot #1)
Author: Agatha Christie

Title: The Ocean at the End of the Lane
Author: Neil Gaiman

Title: And the Mountains Echoed
Author: Khaled Hosseini
My Review:
It hurts me to rate this book as such, but still, I do not think I can rate it any better.

I finished the book last night, and after 6 hours of sleep, none of what I felt through the last half of the book remains inside me. To me, the first half was mesmerizing, the journey of Baba Ayub, the tree in Shadbagh, fifty years of Nabi and Suleiman Wahdati, those are the part that keeps my mind occupied- it is as though the second half never existed. I think the degree to which it's eclipsed by the first half becomes clear from that. The later chapters kept dragging me out of the story- or maybe they were the story, which makes the cover of incoherency achingly translucent.

This is my first book from [a:Khaled Hosseini|569|Khaled Hosseini|https://d.gr-assets.com/authors/1359753468p2/569.jpg], and I do expect better from the other books of him.

Title: The Well of Ascension (Mistborn, #2)
Author: Brandon Sanderson
My Review:
4 for the book, -1 for hidden chauvinism. Surprised?

I disliked the portrayal of Vin strongly. She had the potential to be a strong female character; but in the end she fares little better than Daisy from Great Gatsby - nothing without "her man" beside her. A girl who kills people at night fascinates about ball gowns and men (who can "support" her) is certainly an overkill, and thus an eyesore. It could have been more than that, adding a little character integrity besides her overwhelming "killing machine" aura (which was well-executed, I have to admit) couldn't hurt.

What did I expect, though - this seemed like a teenage fantasy after all.

Title: The Metamorphosis
Author: Franz Kafka
My Review:
Easy on the eyes, hard to digest.

The thing that struck as odd in the first look was certainly the most consistent part- Gregor's behavior. At first, it seems odd, why he would not raise a hue and cry; but then again, he was the one with the deformity and by our social norms he is responsible to blend with the shadows by our "Perfect World Hypothesis" (Good things happen to good people, bad things happen to bad people.)

Short, but not easily forgettable.

Title: To Kill a Mockingbird
Author: Harper Lee
My Review:
An absolutely amazing book.

The description of serious matters as rape and racism through the eyes of a child can easily seem hackneyed, but somehow, it didn't. Rather, the vividness of these, juxtaposed with the early childhood innocence, created a magical feeling. This compelled me to rate this as nothing less than a classic.

The suspense between hope and broken promises, the clash between Scout's innocence and Ewell's unscrupulousness pushes the plot forward - there was barely a boring moment - all without invoking the adrenaline induced excitement.

Recommended to anyone, of any taste and any age.

Title: Slaughterhouse-Five
Author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.
My Review:
"It had to be done," Rumfoord told Billy, speaking of the destruction of Dresden.
"I know," said Billy.
"That's war."
"I know. I'm not complaining"
"It must have been hell on the ground."
"It was," said Billy Pilgrim.
"Pity the men who had to do it."
"I do."
"You must have had mixed feelings, there on the ground."
"It was all right," said Billy. "Everything is all right, and everybody has to do exactly what he does. I learned that on Tralfamadore."

The best part of the book - an seemingly apathetic yet appealing prose.

Title: The Murder of Roger Ackroyd
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review: I didn't know Hercule Poirot is এরকুল পোয়ারো before this book :p well, he certainly lives up to his name, though somehow he lacks the flash some other detective stories have. A nice ending and a nice narration, combined with a carefully constructed plot -certainly a good read.

Title: Batman: The Killing Joke
Author: Alan Moore
My Review:
The coolest thing I read in a long time.
The fact that Joker was supposedly killed here by batman (and which was later confirmed to be the intention later by someone official) makes it even greater. The tension between Batman and Joker, and despite all that, their affinity - is portrayed here quite gracefully by Alan Moore.
Loved it.

Title: Poirot Investigates
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
Might as well, why not?
A nice set of short stories, but might not work so well if you want them for anything other than time passing.

Title: The Hero of Ages (Mistborn, #3)
Author: Brandon Sanderson
My Review:
"The mist hides you, protects you,
Gives you power!"
The end wasn't as per expectation, but that makes it even greater. Exciting to the end, and rarely a slow part within. Nice plot and character development.

Title: Neverwhere
Author: Neil Gaiman
My Review:
Interesting opening but stringy ending. It seemed quite hurried, to be honest.
Though, the book is adapted from a TV series. Had I known that, I might have judged it differently.
Interesting fact - the idea is quite similar to that of the 2012 game DmC (Devil May Cry).
Good for imagination. A nice read.

Title: The Name of the Wind (The Kingkiller Chronicle, #1)
Author: Patrick Rothfuss
My Review:
Disclaimer: No kings were killed or harmed in any way in the story of this book.

Not much action, no major mysteries unraveled. Basically an introduction book, in my opinion - let's see what happens within the next two days.

Title: The Wise Man's Fear (The Kingkiller Chronicle, #2)
Author: Patrick Rothfuss
My Review:
Not a fantasy book, at least not what I had expected anyway.

A boring, incoherent chronicle of an over-competent teen might have been a better title. It was actually some disjoint stories strung together in a very, very clumsy manner - and though I liked Kvothe the supporting characters were very, very superficial.

Pausing the fantasy genre for a while, thanks to Kingkiller Chronicles (and Patrick Rothfuss).

Title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower
Author: Stephen Chbosky
My Review:
“So, this is my life. And I want you to know that I am both happy and sad and I'm still trying to figure out how that could be.”

Though at point to point the description of the teenage years seemed unrealistic, overly simplistic, and sometimes outright nostalgic (as though they are being written by people older than those years), the book is ultimately enjoyable - at some points heartwarming, at some points heart-aching.

Title: Kafka on the Shore
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review:
If you remember me, then I don't care if everyone else forgets.



Quite imperfect on quite many levels.

First of all - there are many logical gaps on the novel - many places where this just doesn't add up. Some things are hinted but never explained, some characters are just laid off without any previous explanations and so on. Also, where Colonel Sanders went, or what was his relations with Johnnie Walker, or even JW's relations with Kafka's father - none of these is explained. I was waiting for a spectacular finish like Wind-up Bird chronicles, and all I got was disappointments.

Still, gave three stars because of some nice and heartwarming quotes - those might help me later.

Title: The Way of Shadows (Night Angel, #1)
Author: Brent Weeks
My Review:
What was it, really?

It felt like the author read some fantasy series recently, and getting inspired from that he started his own series. So far so good, but when the books he has read starts leaking into his writing - plots, twists and all, then his book feels like reading a cut-pasted novel made by a great reader of fantasy genre.

Rating this 3/5 only from pity - this half baked book isn't really worth it.

Title: The Lightning Thief (Percy Jackson and the Olympians, #1)
Author: Rick Riordan
My Review:
An absolutely fantastic book for an specific age group.

Though it can be accused of being influenced by Harry Potter, I think this is absolutely okay.
A nice fantasy book, a nicely constructed world, and a crisp writing style.

Title: The Sea of Monsters (Percy Jackson and the Olympians, #2)
Author: Rick Riordan
My Review:
A nice book for children, I guess.
And also makes a nice instrument for spending time mindlessly.
Though seemed like a repetition of the first book, just shaking up the character settings a bit.

Title: The Titan's Curse (Percy Jackson and the Olympians, #3)
Author: Rick Riordan
My Review:
Not quite unlike the previous two books, but still, has an attraction for which I am continuously reading books from this series.
Nice works by Rick Riordan.

Title: The Battle of the Labyrinth (Percy Jackson and the Olympians, #4)
Author: Rick Riordan
My Review:
A nice and creative story - specially the bit about the Labyrinth and its description.
Other than some tiny bits inside, the story progresses nicely, while every component works together to give it a fine ending.
Not the best written book of the series, obviously, but seriously the one with the best potential.

Title: The Last Olympian (Percy Jackson and the Olympians, #5)
Author: Rick Riordan
My Review:
Disclaimer: This book was rated and reviews by my inner twelve year self. Go figure.

The best book of the series, and definitely the ending this series deserved.
I was definitely a little sad about letting the series end, but I was happier to find an ending like this - an ending that after a long, long time did not disappoint me. The build up was quite spectacular, and though I missed Tyson a bit (I really don't know why; I mean, at first I didn't even like his character) the other characters definitely made up for it. The ending was not bland, either, it makes you smile, literally.

Depicts a perfect childhood, with a place of one's own, some people of one's own and stories of one's own - which is quite deeply satisfying.

If you're below sixteen, please go for this series - it will be your best decision in a long time.

Title: Shadow's Edge (Night Angel, #2)
Author: Brent Weeks
My Review:
One humungous blot in the face of fantasy genre.

There are quite infinitely many lines in this book which would drive you right-out mad. I cannot remember them at this moment, and even if I did, I am not sure I would take the time to write them out.

Recommended if you want brain hemorrhage.

Title: Beyond the Shadows (Night Angel, #3)
Author: Brent Weeks
My Review:
The last action was fair enough, so +1 stars.

Other than that, the book was complete, utter BS. If it makes sense, sorry, but you need a sense check for that.

Title: American Gods (American Gods, #1)
Author: Neil Gaiman
My Review:
It's in the trunk. It was always in the trunk.

This is a book about a man, and some gods - but it was much, much beyond that. It was a journey, an experience, and above all, a work of art.
Every encounter, though not awe-inspiring at the first sight, made a lasting impression, and for that I am grateful; for this book and for the time I spent reading it.

Title: Never Let Me Go
Author: Kazuo Ishiguro
My Review:
Interesting, but very very slow.

From the beginning starts a chronicle of Kathy of her life in Hailsham. While it is not quite bad, it's not that enjoyable either - and with that lukewarm narrative the book failed to stick in my mind.

Title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (Millennium, #1)
Author: Stieg Larsson
My Review:
Quite an interesting read considering this as a detective novel.
Though, could have been better in a lot of places. The story drags a little bit at one-third, where Blomkvist starts his reasearch at Hedeby. The book picks up speed after that, though, so that was quite forgivable.
Another thing, I did not understand what role the last 10% of this book played. Why did we need those, exactly? To end the imaginary war about Wennerstrom that the author did not thing necessary to mention in the middle half of the book at all? Sounded like a completely unrelated part of the story for me.
Overall, it was an okay book, but not something I'd read again.

Title: Fahrenheit 451
Author: Ray Bradbury
My Review: A beautiful book, though somewhat surrealistic from time to time. To me, it seemed like that the writer is quite deliberately staying away from cold, hard realism consciously while trying to express his feelings clearly. Well, at least I think he succeeded in that, and I think even if this  might not be the imminent future, it predicts at least a part of it.

Title: Animal Farm
Author: George Orwell
My Review:
The creatures outside looked from pig to man, and from man to pig, and from pig to man again; but already it was impossible to say which was which.

Surely, comrades, you do not want Jones back?

A great depiction of "governments", or what I see left today in my own land. Every character, every event seems to mock the history books, or rather, life in such a country. I loved this book, the very description and the depiction.

Title: The Eye of the World (Wheel of Time, #1)
Author: Robert Jordan
My Review:
Quite a good start for a lengthy fantasy series.
I liked how Robert Jordan kept room for parallelization - three protagonists in a fantasy series is something new, and I will probably have to wait a bit to find out whether it is a good one.
Still, quite great to read, especially to notice how this book combines many greater elements from fantasy genre - so if you are an old school fantasy lover, pick this up and you won't regret, promise!

Title: The Great Hunt (Wheel of Time, #2)
Author: Robert Jordan
My Review:
A fine fantasy book, albeit a little slow from time to time, but still enjoyable.

Parts I disliked:

1. The description of Seanchan. They sounded like murdering rampaging psychopaths to me. Good way to make people hate your villain, but not so much to make them believable.
2. The final fight of Rand and the aftermath. The sounding of horn was way too anticlimactic.
3. The development of Liandrin. Again, I was made to hate the villain, but literally not knowing why.

Title: Preludes & Nocturnes (The Sandman #1)
Author: Neil Gaiman
Additional Authors: Sam Kieth, Mike Dringenberg, Malcolm Jones III, Todd Klein, Karen  Berger
My Review:
Literature in an unexpected format!

I did not think that comic books could have a significant moral value - till I met [a:Alan Moore|3961|Alan Moore|https://d.gr-assets.com/authors/1304944713p2/3961.jpg] or [a:Neil Gaiman|1221698|Neil Gaiman|https://d.gr-assets.com/authors/1234150163p2/1221698.jpg]. True, I was a fan of Neil Gaiman before it, but I did not expect it to boundaries I unconsciously imposed on the comic book genre.

It was an adventure, or rather the beginning of it, in the perspective of a very curious character. Being not familiar with western folklore, I did not know Sandman from anywhere other than some kid movies. But this shone an entire new light on him; and I liked how Neil Gaiman writes as a character that is at once immortal and on a fine balance between apathy and philanthropy - and really sound like one!

Looking forward to reading all the other books of this series as soon as I can!

Title: The Dragon Reborn (Wheel of Time, #3)
Author: Robert Jordan
My Review:
Fair enough, but I expected better.
What I did not expect is narration from Perrin or Mat's perspective. And somehow, Robert Jordan nailed those chapter. I now feel as if the books felt because it was from their perspective, and not Rand's.
Still, the books are getting somehow more and more weird, and I feel the books are constantly making less sense.

Title: The Doll's House (The Sandman #2)
Author: Neil Gaiman
Additional Authors: Steve Parkhouse, Chris Bachalo, Michael Zulli, Mike Dringenberg, Malcolm Jones III, Todd Klein, Clive Barker
My Review:
I liked 1. the cereal convention, 2. the doll's house, 3. the life of Jed; but all three of them together is a few stories too much.
Still, it was enjoyable, a little less so maybe because I read the book at one sitting.

Title: Dream Country (The Sandman #3)
Author: Neil Gaiman
Additional Authors: Kelley Jones, Charles Vess, Colleen Doran, Malcolm Jones III, Steve Erickson
My Review:
A Dream of a Thousand Cats was great - it was more than great; the art, the characters, and the theme, and how Gaiman portrayed everything in one frame.

Sad part is, I did not get or could not follow "A Midsummer Night's Dream". Maybe I will read the plot synopsis of the play and then try again, but for that 3.5 stars.

Title: The Shadow Rising (Wheel of Time, #4)
Author: Robert Jordan
My Review:
Getting real tired of Rand's polygamy -_-
The book is not much different from the previous ones, as I doubt it won't be different from the later ones too. What was happening keeps happening, what will happen will keep happening too - so if you want an honest review, check something out from the first three books.

Title: The Fires of Heaven (Wheel of Time, #5)
Author: Robert Jordan
My Review:
The only plot points for which this book was worth reading are Siuan Sanche's sacking, her plot and character development with respect to Gareth Bryne, and the last four or five chapters. Other than that, I believe Jordan has surely spent too much time (excruciatingly) detailing fussing over the unnecessary and glossing over the unnecessary. Just thinking that Nyaneve's traveling menagerie got more time than the war at Cairhien sends shivers down my spine.
Get you sh*t together -_-

Title: The Sandman, Vol. 4: Season of Mists (The Sandman, #4)
Author: Neil Gaiman
Additional Authors: Kelley Jones, Mike Dringenberg, Matt Wagner, Dick Giordano, George Pratt, P. Craig Russell, Harlan Ellison
My Review:
The beginning was nice, the build up was excellent, but the ending left more to be desired. There could have been so many endings, so many different possibilities, and Neil chose to end with the most dull/boring one, emerging from a deuce ex machina (yep, you read that right).
Liked: the endless family meeting, the depiction of forgotten deities (that would follow in [b:American Gods|4407|American Gods (American Gods, #1)|Neil Gaiman|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1258417001s/4407.jpg|1970226] ) and the renovation of hell.

Title: Lord of Chaos (Wheel of Time, #6)
Author: Robert Jordan
My Review:
The most half-baked book in the Wheel of Time series yet.
The first 80% of this book is seemingly useless, there are only beginnings but no endings; Robert Jordan spins plot-lines without any apparent interest in binding them together.

The only substantial progress in the books is seemingly from the Aes Sedai front (and the Asha'man of Rand led by Taim.) Other than that, we get no definite conclusion for Elayne, Nynaeve, Mat, Morgase, the Forsaken and plenty others whose characters were seemingly there on their own, without any care for where their own story starts or ends.

Not looking forward for the next book as much, but six books sent me in such a position that I have no choice but to end the series.

Title: After Dark
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review:
Another mesmerizing Murakami book...
Though short, in this book there are every taste of classic Murakami literature - interesting characters, their slow but meaningful interaction and as always, the hint of metaphysics to mean something even deeper.
Nice book if someone wants to start reading [a:Haruki Murakami|3354|Haruki Murakami|https://d.gr-assets.com/authors/1350230608p2/3354.jpg], and I would even suggest reading it before Wind Up Bird Chronicles or Kafka on The Shore.

Title: The Sandman: A Game of You
Author: Neil Gaiman
Additional Authors: Shawn McManus, Colleen Doran, Bryan Talbot, George Pratt, Stan Woch, Dick Giordano, Todd Klein
My Review:
Neil Gaiman is an show-off -- and I love him for it.
What does he not have? A brilliant mind full to bursting with mesmerizing ideas, a penchant to create memorable characters and alluding to them even later on - all those makes him (at least in my eyes) nothing short of a genius. And this book was so, too; with nothing more than a few panels of Morpheus but bristling with his universe; going to show how even characters like Barbara can make an impression on the infinitely huge universe out there, and how "sinner"s like Wanda Alvin can make an impression on these characters' lives.
Wonderful book, though somewhat anti-climactic like the previous one, so 4.49/5 stars.

Title: The Magicians (The Magicians #1)
Author: Lev Grossman
My Review:
Rating increased from 3/5 to 5/5.

SPOILER ALERT: This whole deal is real. No, not the magic part, but the part with power to do anything screwing up our head. We are the living proof of this.

Where real world meets a screwed up Narnia and an inconsistent magic system, you get Magicians.
I know the main focus of the writing was never the magic system, but at least some level of consistency was expected. Magic can do something at sometimes and fail at others at some moments, and there's only a blurry line between them at best; and a humongous overlap at worst. Same goes for characters magical abilities; at one scene Martin stops a class and a school full of professors from getting to him, and on another scene a just out of school like Alice gets him because Martin was weak on basics. Seriously, the professors never thought of those?
Still, the depiction of emotions was good, at very many points of the books. Will look for better read in next books, till then, 3.5/5 seems appropriate.

Title: The Magician King (The Magicians, #2)
Author: Lev Grossman
My Review:
First off - Magician King was a huge improvement over The Magicians; it was the first time it looked like the characters might actually be able to feel something, rather than being animated and just acting so.
The adventure was actually impressive; it was something that actually offered exhilaration rather than just giving off a vague vibe. Finally, the ending was enough tragic that it stuck and didn't feel like it was made to be a soppy, sad story. Overall, I'd give this book a 4.5/5; and I must say, Lev Grossman improved a lot over the years.

Title: The Magician's Land (The Magicians, #3)
Author: Lev Grossman
My Review:
I liked this book pretty much.
Seemed like quite a nice ending to the series - it went well with the vibes and the common themes running through the series. Though some touches were a bit incomplete (like with Asmodeus and such), but in general; it felt good enough.

Bringing back Alice was maybe a little unimportant or childishly done. If a character is dead, I think letting them die is the best choice, rather than having them pop-up somewhere later in the book, trying to rekindle the long-lost love (and long-lost track of love story) isn't something pleasant, even more so when it's done as poorly as in the Magician.

4.5 stars, I guess? And that's when I am being generous.

Title: A Crown of Swords (Wheel of Time, #7)
Author: Robert Jordan

Title: The Path of Daggers (Wheel of Time, #8)
Author: Robert Jordan

Title: The Sandman: Fables & Reflections
Author: Neil Gaiman
Additional Authors: Bryan Talbot, Stan Woch, P. Craig Russell, Shawn McManus, John Watkiss, Jill Thompson, Duncan Eagleson, Kent Williams, Todd Klein

Title: A Memory of Light (Wheel of Time, #14)
Author: Robert Jordan
My Review:
God dammit.
It's done, it's over.
After nearly a year, it's over now. The journey that started with the Eye Of The World ends with A Memory of Light, after so many days and hours spent reading this book.
Fourteen books, each nearly a thousand pages, probably a million words. And now this is done.
I am no state to write a review, maybe someday later when I am less emotional. Not now, certainly not now.

Title: Calamity (The Reckoners, #3)
Author: Brandon Sanderson
My Review:
An interesting take on the idea of superheroes, or more closely, X-men.

Over the whole series, the fight of normal people against epic was pretty deftly depicted, although that did seem to flag a bit in the end. I'd give this book a 3.25, but I feel that's the best Sanderson could have done within the confines of 400 pages.

Title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
Author: Philip K. Dick

Title: The Emperor's Blades (Chronicle of the Unhewn Throne, #1)
Author: Brian Staveley

Title: The Providence of Fire (Chronicle of the Unhewn Throne, #2)
Author: Brian Staveley

Title: The Last Mortal Bond (Chronicle of the Unhewn Throne, #3)
Author: Brian Staveley
My Review:
Took me long enough.
INCREDIBLY drawn out - from the beginning to the very end it felt like nearly every sentence was being repeated thrice, and even after the reader gets how serious the situation is, Staveley just keeps rubbing their nose in that particular grindstone.
Other particular pieces of discontent:


1. Character development for certain characters went horribly wrong somewhere. Like, what was the point of showing Gwenna loves Valyn after reaching the 90% point of the trilogy, if that induces nothing farther in the storyline? Bad decisions all around.



2. Lack of coherence was another itch I couldn't really put past me. Who is going to care for the millions and millions of loose ends that Stavely left around all over the place? What happened to the skullsworn, or why did the pseudo-Kettral come into the story if only to be killed by Baledin 20 seconds into the fight? If this were a movie I would say this is going through a strict budget cut - but it is not; and so I must say this book suffers from the lack of imagination of the author, or simply his lack of concern about these

.

Would have given 2.5/5 stars. Given 3 because of my generosity and some very well written paragraphs (still less than 10) over the whole book.

Title: The Lies of Locke Lamora (Gentleman Bastard, #1)
Author: Scott Lynch

Title: Red Seas Under Red Skies (Gentleman Bastard, #2)
Author: Scott Lynch

Title: The Big Short: Inside the Doomsday Machine
Author: Michael   Lewis

Title: Hard-Boiled Wonderland and the End of the World
Author: Haruki Murakami

Title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child - Parts One and Two (Harry Potter, #8)
Author: John Tiffany

Title: The Trial
Author: Franz Kafka
Additional Authors: Edwin Muir, Willa Muir, Max Brod

Title: Cloud Atlas
Author: David Mitchell
My Review:
If you could create a thing, only one, great, thing, in your lifetime, would you do it?

Cloud Atlas is such a creation from David Mitchell - like the Cloud Atlas Sextet by Robert Frobisher, I would be happy with myself if this book were the only think I ever gave the world. Such neatness that connects one story with another that I never felt lost - instead I just followed along with the narrative as it turned and tossed me first from the past to the future; and then from the future to the past, near the very first point where I started.

Truly, if you are thinking about starting your new year with a new book, pick this up. You will not be disappointed.

Title: The Stranger
Author: Albert Camus
Additional Authors: Stuart Gilbert, Matthew    Ward, Leman Sarı
My Review:
"To feel it so like myself, indeed, so brotherly, made me realize that I’d been happy, and that I was happy still."


Aren't we all?
In the world where apathy makes us guilty, aren't we all a bit of Meursault?
This was always the question, even more so in today's world when we have lost touch with our humanity and having trouble finding it back.

Title: A Clockwork Orange
Author: Anthony Burgess
My Review: I generally do not rate books which are (or try to be) this profound so low, but for a clockwork orange, I had to. It was an okay book with a good message, but the overuse of Russian slang to show the change in society is just poor writing. I believe there were other better ways of doing it, which the author failed to execute. Even more, the ending fell flat, was very poorly explained, and felt a bit rushed while spending so much time went behind developing the introduction. Overall, I think it is a book worth reading, but it is VERY hard to read - and you should keep that in mind when you pick it up.

Title: Ghostwritten
Author: David Mitchell
My Review: Took me a month to read - but well, it was merely okay. Expected better.

Title: Way of the Peaceful Warrior: A Book That Changes Lives
Author: Dan Millman
My Review: Reads like a lot of pseudo-deep divulgence of "wisdom", but I think there is still some spiritual things to learn from here. Good for at least a new outlook on some things in life.

Title: Norse Mythology
Author: Neil Gaiman
My Review:
The gods live, and they die, and they live again.
Have not read such a great book in a long, long time. Neil Gaiman's writing is absolutely refreshing.

Title: Ghost in the Shell (Ghost in the Shell, #1)
Author: Masamune Shirow

Title: A Darker Shade of Magic (Shades of Magic, #1)
Author: V.E. Schwab

Title: The Great Gatsby
Author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
My Review: An absolute masterpiece, this one. I don't know why I could sympathize with Carraway so much, considering we are a century apart - and our backgrounds have nothing in common; but still, how I resonated with his words are truly remarkable. Maybe this is what it means to be a truly great author - that you can make your readers feel what your characters are feeling even after you are long gone.

Title: This Side of Paradise
Author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
My Review:
"I have known myself, but that is all."
Oh Amory, Amory Blaine, the poor, lost youth from the lost generation! Why do I still see you everywhere?

The book read more like an autobiography than a fiction - and I can only imagine how Fitzgerald felt while he wrote the book. His long speech about the upside-down system at the end was still so frighteningly relevant - that it makes me fearful of the future. Then again, a century has passed since then, and we are still here, making slow progress while paving the way with the lives of many. Maybe we will keep going ahead. Maybe the hopes and dreams that we sacrifice on the way today is the fuel for a shinier future. Maybe that's the curse humanity is forced to bear.

I know this review doesn't make much sense. It is not supposed to. I am writing down how reading this book has made me feel.

Title: Poor Economics: A Radical Rethinking of the Way to Fight Global Poverty
Author: Abhijit V. Banerjee
My Review: Things I have seen all my life (or at least in the first 17 years of it), written up in a clear and concise way, with some added hypothesis about why that might be the case.

Title: Sandman Special #1: The Song of Orpheus
Author: Neil Gaiman

Title: The Sandman: Brief Lives (The Sandman #7)
Author: Neil Gaiman
Additional Authors: Jill Thompson, Vince Locke, Peter Straub
My Review:
Why does he have to be so...
The Sandman characters are so removed from life that I can never fathom why they make me feel so strongly. Or maybe because they are so removed from life, so much larger than life itself, that gives it the beauty nothing else could quite capture.

Title: Sputnik Sweetheart
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review: Read the entire book in one day. My only regret now is that there aren't enough books by Murakami in this world - because then I'd hardly read anything else.

Title: Cat's Cradle
Author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.
My Review:
I have always had a penchant for apocalyptic literature. Maybe because I always had the feeling that the world has more of a chance for ending in my age than any others before it.

Would people survive? Probably not.

But what other way can we deal with it, without dealing in satires? Probably not. That's the only weapon we have when the others have ice-nine enough to end the world.

Another weird but excellent book. It deserves every star it got from me.

Title: The Sandman: World's End (The Sandman #8)
Author: Neil Gaiman
Additional Authors: Mike Allred, Gary Amaro, Mark Buckingham, David Giordano, Tony Harris, Steve Leialoha, Vince Locke, Shea Anton Pensa, Alec Stevens, Bryan Talbot, John Watkiss, Todd Klein, Michael Zulli, Stephen King

Title: The Kindly Ones (The Sandman #9)
Author: Neil Gaiman
Additional Authors: Marc Hempel, Richard Case, D'Israeli, Teddy Kristiansen, Glyn Dillon, Charles Vess, Dean Ormston, Kevin Nowlan, Todd Klein, Frank McConnell
My Review:
I hereby declare Sandman a part of me; so whoever loves Sandman loves me.


Wasn't it really inevitable, that the story of Dream had to end this way? I knew what was coming at every step I took towards the end of the story, and yet I read on.

And Gaiman didn't disappoint. It was not some grand battle, it was like how a fire dies, little by little till you cannot remember where.

Still, I loved the little moments of artistry, where the writing touches your heart and kills you at the same time. It was like being granted love and having it taken away - it's hard on you but, you would go through it all over again.

Title: Looking for Alaska
Author: John Green
My Review: Wasn't overwhelmed. Yes, I was concerned, but that was ultimately the strongest feeling this book made me feel :(

Title: The Wake (The Sandman #10)
Author: Neil Gaiman
Additional Authors: Michael Zulli, Jon J. Muth, Charles Vess, Mikal Gilmore
My Review:
The epic saga finally ends :)
And what an ending it was! I could write a hundred words about why "The Wake" is a perfect title for this series. But I will not.

Because sometimes, what's needed more is to mourn someone you loved. And then to move on.
And that's what I am going to do. For Morpheus. For nothing more than a point of view, on things, an endless series of observation that also gave rise to infinite joy.

I hope I come upon another series that might be as good. But even if I don't, I hope I remember this.
Because, as Neil wrote, "Everything changes, but nothing is truly lost."

Title: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
Author: James Joyce
My Review:
The three stars will fool you only if you let them to.
I would say it is so much more for my inability to grasp the book's true meaning than its inability to convey it. Maybe I will come back once I have seen more of life, and then I will understand more of it.
At least I could really relate to Dedalus's perspective on religion. Interesting how these still stay relevant even after a hundred years.
